content.description: Start on jug rail, paste feet high and use a combination of balance/reach/dyno to snag the decent lip. Be mindful of the fall potential and press out a difficult mantle. Pad & spotter recommended.
content.location: Immediately to the left of the main trailside boulder.

content.description: Sustained technical climbing on small edges yields to a slopey shelf and easy top-out.
content.location: 6 feet to the right of the other unnamed line on the boulder, facing the trail. Start matched on the ear hold at chest height. Make technical moves left and up (potentially doing an awesome chicken wing lock-off) to join the other line at the slopey shelf.

content.description: Surprisingly good granite bouldering. Start on 2 edges at ~6 feet on the left side of the main face. Make a cruxy move up to the sloping shelf, and then a few technical moves (potentially using a suspect crimp up high) to get your feet established on the shelf. Easy top-out.
content.location: Obvious face directly on the trail, can't miss it.

content.description: Start on angular jug ~4 feet off the ground. Make a long pull to an even better jug and top out by either escaping to the left or going directly up (better, more fun).
content.location: On the boulder to the right of the main trailside boulder. This boulder comprises one wall of the little chimney.

content.description: Stand start on two right-facing sidepulls on the slabby face to the right of the face directly on the trail. Gain the thin rail halfway up the slabby scoop and employ some finesse to get your feet onto that rail. From there you can either go up direct (using a highly suspect flake over a bad fall), or better, trend slightly left on interesting holds and easier ground.
content.location: Immediately to the right of the two vertical lines on the trailside boulder.

content.description: Start on crappy razor crimp and blast one move up and left to a good edge. Top out.
content.location: If taking the Dave Moore loop counter-clockwise, take the first river access trail. The boulder is 50 feet to your right once you hit the small beach.

content.description: The obvious hard line on the main trailside boulder. Start on the left arete with crimps at head height. Make a couple of difficult moves on thin crimps (one is an amazing 5 mm razor with awesome texture!), avoiding holds out and right, before pulling into the corner above with difficulty. Finish up easier climbing, topping out at the highest point on the boulder. Will be pretty cool when the full line goes!
content.location: Left-most line on the main trailside boulder, immediately right of the dirty offwidth grovel. Look for decent crimps at head height (lower options exist, but don't make too much sense unless you're looking to add a full sit-start).

content.description: Striking parallel fist crack that surmounts a bulge before yielding to a jug at the apex of the crack. Fun little grunt fest, and the best-looking line in the cluster.
content.location: 20 feet off the trail, on the largest satellite to the trailside boulder.

content.description: Do you dream of 3 mediocre chimney moves (4 if you make it a sit-start)? Well have I got the boulder for you...could be a fun bombay chimney for the vertically disinclined.
content.location: Between two outcroppings of rock immediately to the right of the main trailside boulder. Easily overlooked (and rightfully so).

content.description: Immediately right of the unnamed V3, start on a cool angular right-facing jug at chest height. Figure out how to enter the offwidth crack and grunt to victory. Crux is likely getting established in the crack and fighting the moss, assuming you didn't use the rock at your lower left for feet.
content.location: 5 feet right of the unnamed V3 dyno-ish problem.
